summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against Marty Croft, a convicted felon who was sentenced to 40 years in prison for child molestation, aggravated sexual battery, and false imprisonment.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Atlanta, Georgia, alleges that Croft violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The complaint also alleges that in 2011, when Croft was visiting his aunt and uncle, he began to molest her, kissing her neck, breasts, stomach, and back even though she told him to stop, and threatened to have her father sent to prison if she told anyone about the contact. In 2014, after a jury found Croft guilty on all of these counts, the court ordered Croft to be barred from the jury room for the rest of his life. The court also ordered that he pay a civil penalty of $10,000. Croft agreed to settle the SEC's charges by consenting to the entry of a judgment that permanently restrains and enjoins him from future violations of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 16(a)(2) of The Securities Act, and orders him to pay disgorgement of $7,829.95 plus prejudgment interest of $1,822.95 and a $2,500 civil penalty. The settlement is subject to court approval.  In a parallel action, the U. S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Georgia today announced criminal charges against Croft.  Among other things, the SEC today announced that it has obtained a temporary restraining order halting Croft from appearing or practicing before the SEC as part of a criminal case. The SEC previously issued an order freezing Croft’s assets and ordering him to return to the United States and pay civil penalties of $15,000 each.  According to the SEC, Croft consented to the issuance of the order, without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC complaint, that he had violated Section 5(b)(5) and (c) and Rule 5b2-1 thereunder, and that he would be liable for the amount of his prison time. The order also prohibits him from serving as an officer or director of a public company and from participating in any offering of a penny stock or offering of any penny stock.
